Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Mechanical/Chemical Failure of Solid Electrolyte Interphase in Lithium-ion Batteries: Understanding Its Mechanisms and Suppressing Its Onset

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Jonghyun Park
Proposal Number: 1510085

Lithium ion batteries support the development of sustainable energy systems by storing electricity generated by renewable resources such as wind and solar energy, or by powering zero-emission electric vehicles charged by electricity from renewable resources. However, current rechargeable lithium ion batteries can hold only about 10% of their theoretical energy content, and new concepts are needed to improve energy storage capacity and power discharge rate. The addition of the metal germanium to lithium ion battery electrodes offers the potential to improve both storage capacity and power. However, the germanium swells significantly upon charging and discharging, which cracks the battery and renders it useless. The goals of this project are to determine the mechanisms of the failure process, and then to use this fundamental understanding to develop coating materials and processes for the germanium particles that will control the swelling behavior. The educational activities associated with this project include efforts to broaden participation by involving undergraduates from nearly Lincoln University of Missouri in the proposed research.

The use of geranium (Ge) metal in the solid interface layer of the anode of lithium ion batteries offers the potential for high theoretical electrochemical energy storage capacity and power discharge rate. However, upon repeated charge/discharge cycles, the solid electrolyte interface layer of the anode breaks down. The damage to the solid electrolyte layer is due to the mechanical volume change in Ge metal during lithium-ion insertion (charging) and extraction (discharge), which causes cracks and pulverization of this layer that lead to loss of electrode contact and dissolution of the solid electrolyte layer into the electrolyte. The goals of the research are to characterize the mechanisms of failure in the Ge anode, and then use this fundamental understanding to develop fabrication strategies for suppressing these damage processes by controlling internal structure of the solid electrolyte layer containing Ge nanoparticles, as well as its interface with active materials. The mechanisms of failure will be elucidated by characterizing mechanical strength and chemical dissolution rate of the solid interface layer components. The internal structure of the solid interface layer will be controlled by using Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) to coat additive materials, for example metal oxides, onto Ge nanoparticles in the attempt to reduce stress upon lithium ion insertion and extraction. A multiscale model will be developed that couples the nanoparticle level behavior in the solid interface layer to electrochemical cell operation to predict the conditions that trigger solid interface layer failure and its subsequent effect on battery performance. This model will then be used to identify strategies to optimize the ALD materials and process for improved mechanical stability and battery performance. To connect the research to education, the PI will introduce energy materials and battery design concepts in a capstone mechanical engineering capstone design course, and will give demonstrations on lithium-ion battery coin cell assembly for undergraduate and K-12 students at the Missouri University of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objectives of the proposed research are to characterize the mechanisms of the failure of the Solid Electrolyte Interphase (SEI) layer in the lithium ion battery anodes and then use the information obtained to find a solution whereby the failure can be suppressed by controlling the internal structure of the SEI layer and its interface with the active materials. The main outcomes of this project are listed as follow:

In our preliminary study (published in Advanced Materials Interfaces, data reported in the proposal), we found ion conductive CeO2 films can greatly improve both the initial capacity and charge/discharge cycling life time of LiMn2O4 cathode materials. We continued the work to reveal the mechanism of this performance enhancement through theoretical and experimental observation. Then, the idea was moved to other materials. First, various thicknesses of alumina ALD films were coated on Ge nanoparticles and fabricated Ge anode electrodes. The coated Ge nanoparticles and electrodes were characterized. The electrochemical performance of alumina ALD films coated Ge anode electrodes were tested. It was observed that the adhesiveness of the active material to the current collector was poor. Next, both PVDF and PAA were tested for Ge electrode fabrication, and PVDF was found to be more thermodynamically stable as compared to PAA. We expanded the ALD thin film coating to other lithium ion battery electrode materials. For example, we coated iron oxide films on SnO2 particles by ALD, and found that iron oxide ALD coating greatly improved the performance of SnO2 as lithium ion battery anode materials. We coated iron oxide (FeOx) films by ALD on Li1.2Mn0.54Ni0.13Co0.13O2 particles and significantly improved the electrochemical performance of the cathode material. We coated TiN films on LiFePO4 particles by ALD, and found that TiN ALD coating greatly improved the performance of LiFePO4 as lithium ion battery cathode materials.

Simultaneously, we have investigated the mechanism how a thin coating can improve the battery performance. An investigation was conducted using first principles calculations, focused on energetic preferences, transport, and structural changes. We examined the properties of ALD layer from the atomic level through DFT (density functional theory) calculation by focusing on lithium-ion formation energy, diffusivity, and corresponding volume change in the coating layer. We also have developed a multiscale-controlled battery geometry by using 3D printing and ALD coating based on LiMn1.5Ni0.5O4 material. This exhibited the highest areal capacity (3.5 mAh/cm2) along with high specific capacity (130 mAh/g).

For the education part, total five PhD students and one MS student involved in this project and exposed to the cutting-edge thin film coating technology, lithium ion batteries, and DFT. Training on thin coating deposition, characterizations of thin coatings, assembly of lithium ion battery coin cells, battery testing, and modeling will well establish their skills and critical thinking for their future careers. One MS student from the co-PI’s group graduated with thesis. Two PhD students from the PI’s group already graduated, and one PhD student from the co-PI’s group is expected to graduate in May 2020. Five undergraduate students (including two REU students and two OURE students, and two of them are female) and four high school students involved in this project, which helped them understand basic engineering concepts and grasp basic experimental skills.

For the dissemination of research outcomes, seven journal papers have been published based on this project, and four manuscripts are pending. The PIs or their PhD students attend 7 conferences and made 14 presentations. The PI worked closely with the co-PI and has established a fruitful research and educational relationship. Some demonstration modules have been developed for K-12 students. More than 60 girls entering 9-10th grades attended a "Nano Nano" workshop in the co-PI’s group for the Summer Solutions Camp in the last four years.

The outcomes of this project are expected to have great scientific as well as technological impact on the development of lithium ion batteries. Understanding the links between the atomic scale, microstructure, macroscopic properties, and failure is one of the fundamental challenges in the mechanics of battery materials. The knowledge and approaches gained from this investigation will be of particular use to the battery community.
